body:
# permafrost

Permafrost implements a (relatively) fast unordered persistent map. Plus a set
and a bidirectional map based on the map.

## Installation

1. Add the dependency to your `shard.yml`:

   ```yaml
   dependencies:
     permafrost:
       github: homonoidian/permafrost
   ```

2. Run `shards install`

## Usage

I implemented most useful stuff (?) from `Hash` and `Set`. `BidiMap` is mostly for myself
so you may forget it exists :) All in all refer to [the docs](https://homonoidian.github.io/permafrost/).

```crystal
require "permafrost"

map = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]
map["foo"]? # => 100
map["bar"]? # => 200

map.assoc("baz", 300) # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 100, "bar" => 200, "baz" => 300}
map                   # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 100, "bar" => 200}

map.dissoc("foo") # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 200}
map               # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 100, "bar" => 200}
```

## Development

The implementation is pretty simple, it's found in `src/permafrost/core/node.cr`.
If you find any errors please let me know or (even better!) fix them yourself and
submit a PR. Same with new features.

## See also

I've no clue whether what I've written truly is a HAMT or not, as long
as it works I'm fine. Here are some "true" HAMTs:

- [Immutable](https://github.com/lucaong/immutable)
- [HAMT for C with good internals explanation](https://github.com/mkirchner/hamt)
- [Clojure's PersistentHashMap](https://github.com/clojure/clojure/blob/master/src/jvm/clojure/lang/PersistentHashMap.java)
- etc.

## Contributing

1. Fork it (<https://github.com/homonoidian/permafrost/fork>)
2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b my-new-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -am 'Add some feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin my-new-feature`)
5. Create a new Pull Request

## Contributors

- [Alexey Yurchenko](https://github.com/homonoidian) - creator and maintainer

types.name: Enumerable
types.doc:
The `Enumerable` mixin provides collection classes with several traversal, searching,
filtering and querying methods.

Including types must provide an `each` method, which yields successive members
of the collection.

For example:

```
class Three
  include Enumerable(Int32)

  def each(&)
    yield 1
    yield 2
    yield 3
  end
end

three = Three.new
three.to_a                # => [1, 2, 3]
three.select &.odd?       # => [1, 3]
three.all? { |x| x < 10 } # => true
```

Note that most search and filter methods traverse an Enumerable eagerly,
producing an `Array` as the result. For a lazy alternative refer to
the `Iterator` and `Iterable` modules.
types.summary: The Enumerable mixin provides collection classes with several traversal, searching, filtering and querying methods.

instance_methods.name: to_pf_bidi
instance_methods.doc:
Like `to_pf_map`, but creates a `Pf::BidiMap`.

```
(0...10).zip('a'...'z').to_pf_bidi # => Pf::BidiMap{0 <=> 'a', 1 <=> 'b', 2 <=> 'c', ...}
```
instance_methods.summary: Like #to_pf_map, but creates a Pf::BidiMap.

instance_methods.name: to_pf_map
instance_methods.doc:
Creates a `Pf::Map` out of `{key, value}` tuple pairs returned
by the block.

```
(0...10).to_pf_map { |n| {n, n * 2} } # => Pf::Map{2 => 4, 3 => 6, 4 => 8, ...}
```
instance_methods.summary: Creates a Pf::Map out of {key, value} tuple pairs returned by the block.

def.name: to_pf_map
def.body:
reduce(Pf::Map(K, V).new) do |map, el|
  map.assoc(*yield el)
end

instance_methods.name: to_pf_map
instance_methods.doc:
Creates a `Pf::Map` out of an Enumerable whose elements respond
to `.[0]` and `.[1]`.

```
(0...10).zip('a'..'z').to_pf_map # => Pf::Map{0 => 'a', 1 => 'b', 2 => 'c', ...}
```
instance_methods.summary: Creates a Pf::Map out of an Enumerable whose elements respond to .[0] and .[1].

instance_methods.name: to_pf_set
instance_methods.doc:
Creates a `Pf::Set` out of an Enumerable.

```
(0...5).to_pf_set # => Pf::Set[0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
```
instance_methods.summary: Creates a Pf::Set out of an Enumerable.

types.name: BidiMap
types.doc:
A thread-safe, persistent, unordered bidirectional map.

See also: `Map`.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: Returns a map with mappings from an *enumerable* of key-value pairs.
constructors.summary: Returns a map with mappings from an enumerable of key-value pairs.

def.name: new
def.body:
enumerable.reduce(BidiMap(K, V).new) do |bidi, __temp_60|
  k, v = __temp_60
  bidi.assoc(k, v)
end

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Returns a new empty `BidiMap`.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap(String, Int32).new
bidi.empty? # => true
```

def.name: new
def.body: new(valueof: Pf::Map(K, V).new, keyof: Pf::Map(V, K).new)

instance_methods.name: assoc
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` that contains the mapping of *key* to
*value*. and of *value* to *key*.

*Supports value equality*.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap(String, Int32).new
bidi.assoc("hello", 100) # => Pf::BidiMap{"hello" <=> 100}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self that contains the mapping of key to value.

def.name: assoc
def.body:
keyof = (v = value_for?(key)) ? @keyof.dissoc(v) : @keyof
valueof = (k = key_for?(value)) ? @valueof.dissoc(k) : @valueof
BidiMap.new(valueof.assoc(key, value), keyof.assoc(value, key))

instance_methods.name: dissoc_by_key
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` which is guaranteed not to have a mapping
with the given *key*.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.dissoc_by_key(:foo) # => Pf::BidiMap{:bar <=> 200}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self which is guaranteed not to have a mapping with the given key.

def.name: dissoc_by_key
def.body:
if value = value_for?(key)
else
  return self
end
BidiMap.new(@valueof.dissoc(key), @keyof.dissoc(value))

instance_methods.name: dissoc_by_value
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` which is guaranteed not to have a mapping
with the given *value*.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.dissoc_by_value(200) # => Pf::BidiMap{:foo <=> 100}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self which is guaranteed not to have a mapping with the given value.

def.name: dissoc_by_value
def.body:
if key = key_for?(value)
else
  return self
end
BidiMap.new(@valueof.dissoc(key), @keyof.dissoc(value))

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.doc: Yields each key-value pair to the block.
instance_methods.summary: Yields each key-value pair to the block.

instance_methods.name: empty?
instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if this map contains no mappings.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this map contains no mappings.

instance_methods.name: has_key_for?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if this map contains a mapping with the given *value*.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.has_key_for?(100) # => true
bidi.has_key_for?(200) # => true
bidi.has_key_for?(300) # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this map contains a mapping with the given value.

instance_methods.name: has_value_for?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if this map contains a mapping with the given *key*.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.has_value_for?(:foo) # => true
bidi.has_value_for?(:bar) # => true
bidi.has_value_for?(:baz) # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this map contains a mapping with the given key.

instance_methods.name: key_for
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the key mapped to the given *value*. If there is no such
key raises `KeyError`.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.key_for(100) # => :foo
bidi.key_for(200) # => :bar
bidi.key_for(300) # raises KeyError
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the key mapped to the given value.

instance_methods.name: key_for?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the key mapped to the given *value*, or nil if there is
no such key.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.key_for?(100) # => :foo
bidi.key_for?(200) # => :bar
bidi.key_for?(300) # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the key mapped to the given value, or nil if there is no such key.

def.name: pretty_print
def.body:
pp.list("Pf::BidiMap{", self, "}") do |k, v|
  pp.group do
    k.pretty_print(pp)
    pp.text(" <=>")
    pp.nest do
      pp.breakable
      v.pretty_print(pp)
    end
  end
end

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc: Returns the number of mappings.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of mappings.

def.name: to_s
def.body:
io << "Pf::BidiMap{"
join(io, ", ") do |__temp_61|
  k, v = __temp_61
  k.inspect(io)
  io << " <=> "
  v.inspect(io)
end
io << "}"

instance_methods.name: value_for
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the value mapped to the given *key*. If there is no such
value raises `KeyError`.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.value_for(:foo) # => 100
bidi.value_for(:bar) # => 200
bidi.value_for(:baz) # raises KeyError
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the value mapped to the given key.

instance_methods.name: value_for?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the value mapped to the given *key*, or nil if there is
no such value.

```
bidi = Pf::BidiMap.assoc(:foo, 100).assoc(:bar, 200)
bidi.value_for?(:foo) # => 100
bidi.value_for?(:bar) # => 200
bidi.value_for?(:baz) # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the value mapped to the given key, or nil if there is no such value.

types.name: Eq
types.doc:
Includers are `Pf::Map` value types whose `#==` method can be used
to determine whether two values are equal after reassignment. This
helps to avoid path copying if the values do indeed turn out equal.
types.summary: Includers are Pf::Map value types whose #== method can be used to determine whether two values are equal after reassignment.

types.name: Map
types.doc:
A thread-safe, persistent, unordered hash map.

## Value equality

Being a persistent map, `Pf::Map` tries to avoid path copying. This
is done by comparing the old and new values using `==`. In particular,
methods that *support value equality* do so.

Note that, out of the box, `==` is called only when your value is
of the types `nil`, `Bool`, `Char`, `String`, `Symbol`, or of a
primitive number type.

`same?` is called on all reference (`Reference`) types.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]
map.assoc("foo", 100).same?(map)             # => true, no change
map.update("foo", 0, &.succ.pred).same?(map) # => true, no change

map2 = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]
map.merge(map2).same?(map)  # => true, no change
map2.merge(map).same?(map2) # => true, no change
```

If you want to enable `==` for our own object, you should include
`Pf::Eq`.

```
record Info, first_name : String, last_name : String

people = Pf::Map
  .assoc(0, Info.new("John", "Doe"))
  .assoc(1, Info.new("Barbara", "Doe"))

people.assoc(0, Info.new("John", "Doe")).same?(people) # => false

struct Info
  include Pf::Eq
end

people.assoc(0, Info.new("John", "Doe")).same?(people) # => true
```

Since `BidiMap` is backed by `Map`, the same applies to it. On the
other hand, elements of a `Set` are *keys* so they are always compared
using `==` eventually.

class_methods.doc:
A shorthand syntax for creating a `Map` with string keys. The type
of the map's values is the union of the types of values in *entries*.

```
map = Pf::Map[name: "John Doe", age: 25]
map["name"] # => "John Doe"
map["age"]  # => 25

typeof(map) # => Pf::Map(String, String | Int32)
```
class_methods.summary: A shorthand syntax for creating a Map with string keys.

def.body:
map = Map(String, typeof(Enumerable.element_type(entries.values))).new
entries.each do |k, v|
  map = map.assoc(k.to_s, v)
end
map

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: Returns a map with mappings from an *enumerable* of key-value pairs.
constructors.summary: Returns a map with mappings from an enumerable of key-value pairs.

def.name: new
def.body:
enumerable.reduce(Map(K, V).new) do |map, __temp_49|
  k, v = __temp_49
  map.assoc(k, v)
end

instance_methods.doc:
Compares `self` with *other*. Returns `true` if all mappings are
the same (values are compared using `==`).
instance_methods.summary: Compares self with other.

def.body:
if same?(other)
  return true
end
if size == other.size
else
  return false
end
each do |k, v1|
  v2 = other.fetch(k) do
    return false
  end
  if v1 == v2
  else
    return false
  end
end
true

instance_methods.doc:
Returns the value mapped to *key*. Raises `KeyError` if there is
no such value.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 10]
map["foo"] # => 10
map["bar"] # raises KeyError
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the value mapped to key.

instance_methods.doc:
Traverses nested maps/`Hash`es and returns the value. Raises
`KeyError` if there is no value.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: Pf::Map[bar: {100 => Pf::Map[baz: "Yay!"]}]]
map["foo", "bar", 100, "baz"] # => "Yay!"
map["foo", "bar", 200]        # raises KeyError
```
instance_methods.summary: Traverses nested maps/Hashes and returns the value.

instance_methods.doc:
Returns the value mapped to *key*, or nil if *key* is absent.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 10, bar: 20]
map["foo"]? # => 10
map["bar"]? # => 20
map["baz"]? # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the value mapped to key, or nil if key is absent.

instance_methods.doc:
Traverses nested maps/`Hash`es and returns the value, or `nil` if
the value is absent.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: Pf::Map[bar: {100 => Pf::Map[baz: "Yay!"]}]]
map["foo", "bar", 100, "baz"]? # => "Yay!"
map["foo", "bar", 200]?        # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Traverses nested maps/Hashes and returns the value, or nil if the value is absent.

instance_methods.name: assoc
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` that contains the mapping of *key* to *value*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map(String, Int32).new

branch1 = map.assoc("foo", 100)
branch2 = map.assoc("foo", 200)

map = map.assoc("bar", 300)

map["foo"]? # => nil
map["bar"]? # => 300

branch1["foo"]? # => 100
branch1["bar"]? # => nil

branch2["foo"]? # => 200
branch2["bar"]? # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self that contains the mapping of key to value.

instance_methods.name: clone
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new `Map` whose values are deeply cloned versions of
those from `self`. That is, returns a deep copy of `self`.

Keys are not cloned (if you need to clone keys then the last thing
to help you is a persistent immutable map!).

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: [1, 2, 3], bar: [4, 5, 6]]
map2 = map.clone

map["foo"][0] = 100

map  # => Pf::Map{"foo" => [100, 2, 3], "bar" => [4, 5, 6]}
map2 # => Pf::Map{"foo" => [1, 2, 3], "bar" => [4, 5, 6]}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new Map whose values are deeply cloned versions of those from self.

def.name: clone
def.body:
{% if (((((V == ::Nil) || (V == ::Bool)) || (V == ::Char)) || (V == ::String)) || (V == ::Symbol)) || V < ::Number::Primitive %}
        return self
      {% end %}
reduce(Map(K, V).new) do |map, __temp_58|
  k, v = __temp_58
  map.assoc(k.clone, v.clone)
end

instance_methods.name: compact
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` without `nil` values.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: nil, bar: 123]
map.compact # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 123}

typeof(map)         # => Pf::Map(String, Int32?)
typeof(map.compact) # => Pf::Map(String, Int32)
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self without nil values.

def.name: compact
def.body:
reduce(Map(K, typeof((Enumerable.element_type(self))[1].not_nil!)).new) do |map, __temp_57|
  k, v = __temp_57
  v ? map.assoc(k, v) : map
end

instance_methods.name: dissoc
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` that is guaranteed not to contain a mapping
for *key*.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]

branch1 = map.dissoc("foo")
branch2 = map.dissoc("bar")

map["foo"]? # => 100
map["bar"]? # => 200

branch1["foo"]? # => nil
branch1["bar"]? # => 200

branch2["foo"]? # => 100
branch2["bar"]? # => nil
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self that is guaranteed not to contain a mapping for key.

instance_methods.doc: Yields each key-value pair to the block.

instance_methods.doc: Yields each key to the block.

instance_methods.doc: Yields each value to the block.

def.name: each_value
def.body:
each do |_, v|
  yield v
end

instance_methods.name: empty?
instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if this map contains no mappings.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this map contains no mappings.

instance_methods.name: fetch
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the value mapped to *key*, or yields if *key* is absent.
This method mainly exists to circumvent nil as in value vs. nil
as in absence issue.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the value mapped to key, or yields if key is absent.

def.name: fetch
def.body:
if cloak = @node.find?(key)
else
  return yield
end
cloak.unwrap

instance_methods.name: fmap
instance_methods.doc:
Same as `map`, but returns `Map` instead of an array.

If the block returns more than one value for the same key, the last
yielded value is preferred.

Supports value equality if `K == K2` and `V == V2`.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: "John Doe", bar: "Samantha Doe"]
map.fmap { |k, v| {k.upcase, v.upcase} } # => Pf::Map{"FOO" => "JOHN DOE", "BAR" => "SAMANTHA DOE"}
```
instance_methods.summary: Same as map, but returns Map instead of an array.

def.name: fmap

instance_methods.name: has_key?
instance_methods.doc: Alias of `includes?`.
instance_methods.summary: Alias of #includes?.

instance_methods.name: hash
instance_methods.doc: See `Object#hash(hasher)`
instance_methods.summary: See Object#hash(hasher)

def.name: hash
def.body:
result = hasher.result
copy = hasher
copy = self.class.hash(copy)
result = result &+ copy.result
each do |k, v|
  copy = hasher
  copy = k.hash(copy)
  copy = v.hash(copy)
  result = result &+ copy.result
end
result.hash(hasher)

instance_methods.name: includes?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if *key* is present in this map.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]
"foo".in?(map) # => true
"bar".in?(map) # => true
"baz".in?(map) # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if key is present in this map.

def.name: includes?
def.body:
fetch(key) do
  return false
end
true

instance_methods.name: keys
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an array with all keys from this map. There is no
guaranteed order of keys.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 10, bar: 20]
map.keys # => ["foo", "bar"]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns an array with all keys from this map.

def.name: keys
def.body:
keys = Array(K).new(size)
each_key do |key|
  keys << key
end
keys

instance_methods.name: map_key
instance_methods.doc:
Transforms keys: same as `fmap`, but only yields keys from this map.

Supports value equality if `K == K2`.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: "John Doe", bar: "Samantha Doe"]
map.map_key(&.upcase) # => Pf::Map{"FOO" => "John Doe", "BAR" => "Samantha Doe"}
```
instance_methods.summary: Transforms keys: same as #fmap, but only yields keys from this map.

def.name: map_key

instance_methods.name: map_value
instance_methods.doc:
Transforms values: same as `fmap`, but only yields values from
this map.

Supports value equality if `V == V2`.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: "John Doe", bar: "Samantha Doe"]
map.map_value(&.upcase) # => Pf::Map{"foo" => "JOHN DOE", "bar" => "SAMANTHA DOE"}
```
instance_methods.summary: Transforms values: same as #fmap, but only yields values from this map.

def.name: map_value

instance_methods.name: merge
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new map with mappings from `self` and *other* combined.

If some key is common both to `self` and *other*, *other*'s value
is preferred.

Supports value equality if `K == K2` and `V == V2`.

```
a = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]
b = Pf::Map[foo: "hello", baz: true, boo: 500]

map = a.merge(b)
map # => Pf::Map{"foo" => "hello", "bar" => 200, "baz" => true, "boo" => 500}

typeof(map) # => Pf::Map(String, String | Int32 | Bool)
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new map with mappings from self and other combined.
instance_methods.args_string: (other : Map(K2, V2)) : Map(K | K2, V | V2) forall K2, V2
instance_methods.args_html: (other : Map(K2, V2)) : Map(K | K2, V | V2) forall K2, V2

def.name: merge
def.body:
acc = Map(K | K2, V | V2).new
acc = reduce(acc) do |map, __temp_51|
  k, v1 = __temp_51
  map.assoc(k.as(K | K2), v1.as(V | V2))
end
other.reduce(acc) do |map, __temp_52|
  k, v2 = __temp_52
  map.assoc(k.as(K | K2), v2.as(V | V2))
end

instance_methods.name: merge
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new map with mappings from `self` and *other* combined.

If some key is common both to `self` and *other*, that key is
yielded to the block together with the two values. The return
value of the block is used as the final value.

```
a = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200, baz: 300]
b = Pf::Map[foo: 200, bar: 300.8, boo: 1000.5]

map = a.merge(b) { |k, v1, v2| v1 + v2 }
map # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 300, "bar" => 500.8, "baz" => 300, "boo" => 1000.5}

typeof(map) # => Pf::Map(String, Int32 | Float64)
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new map with mappings from self and other combined.
instance_methods.args_string: (other : Map(K2, V2), & : K, V, V2 -> V | V2) : Map(K | K2, V | V2) forall K2, V2
instance_methods.args_html: (other : Map(K2, V2), & : K, V, V2 -> V | V2) : Map(K | K2, V | V2) forall K2, V2

def.name: merge
def.body:
acc = Map(K | K2, V | V2).new
acc = reduce(acc) do |map, __temp_53|
  k, v1 = __temp_53
  map.assoc(k.as(K | K2), v1.as(V | V2))
end
other.reduce(acc) do |map, __temp_54|
  k, v2 = __temp_54
  k = k.as(K | K2)
  if v1 = acc[k]?
    map.assoc(k, (yield k.as(K), v1.as(V), v2.as(V2)).as(V | V2))
  else
    map.assoc(k, v2.as(V | V2))
  end
end

def.name: pretty_print
def.body:
pp.list("Pf::Map{", self, "}") do |k, v|
  pp.group do
    k.pretty_print(pp)
    pp.text(" =>")
    pp.nest do
      pp.breakable
      v.pretty_print(pp)
    end
  end
end

instance_methods.name: reject
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` which includes only mappings for which
the block is *falsey*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 2, bar: 3, baz: 4, boo: 5]
map.reject { |_, v| v.even? } # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 3, "boo" => 5}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self which includes only mappings for which the block is falsey.

def.name: reject
def.body:
reduce(self) do |map, __temp_56|
  k, v = __temp_56
  yield({k, v}) ? map.dissoc(k) : map
end

instance_methods.name: reject
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new map which is guaranteed not to include the given *keys*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 2, bar: 3, baz: 4, boo: 5]
map.reject({"foo", "boo"}) # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 3, "baz" => 4}
map.reject("foo", "boo")   # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 3, "baz" => 4}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new map which is guaranteed not to include the given keys.

instance_methods.name: reject
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new map which is guaranteed not to include the given *keys*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 2, bar: 3, baz: 4, boo: 5]
map.reject({"foo", "boo"}) # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 3, "baz" => 4}
map.reject("foo", "boo")   # => Pf::Map{"bar" => 3, "baz" => 4}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new map which is guaranteed not to include the given keys.

instance_methods.name: same?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if `self` and *other* refer to the same map in memory.

Due to the way `Map` is implemented, this method can be used as
a cheap way to detect changes.

```
map1 = Pf::Map[foo: 123, bar: 456]
map2 = map1.assoc("foo", 123)
map1.same?(map2) # => true
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if self and other refer to the same map in memory.

instance_methods.name: select
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of `self` which includes only mappings for which
the block is *truthy*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 2, bar: 3, baz: 4, boo: 5]
map.select { |_, v| v.even? } # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 2, "baz" => 4}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of self which includes only mappings for which the block is truthy.

def.name: select
def.body:
reduce(self) do |map, __temp_55|
  k, v = __temp_55
  yield({k, v}) ? map : map.dissoc(k)
end

instance_methods.name: select
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new map which includes only mappings with the given *keys*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 2, bar: 3, baz: 4, boo: 5]
map.select({"foo", "boo"}) # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 2, "boo" => 5}
map.select("foo", "boo")   # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 2, "boo" => 5}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new map which includes only mappings with the given keys.

def.name: select
def.body:
keys.reduce(Map(K, V).new) do |map, k|
  (  v = self[k]?) ? map.assoc(k, v) : map
end

instance_methods.name: select
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new map which includes only mappings with the given *keys*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 2, bar: 3, baz: 4, boo: 5]
map.select({"foo", "boo"}) # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 2, "boo" => 5}
map.select("foo", "boo")   # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 2, "boo" => 5}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new map which includes only mappings with the given keys.

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc: Returns the number of mappings.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of mappings.

def.name: to_s
def.body:
io << "Pf::Map{"
join(io, ", ") do |__temp_59|
  k, v = __temp_59
  k.inspect(io)
  io << " => "
  v.inspect(io)
end
io << "}"

instance_methods.name: update
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an updated copy of `self`.

- If there is no mapping for *key*, the copy contains a mapping of
*key* to *default*.

- If there is a mapping for *key*, its value is yielded to the block
and the return value of the block is used as the next value of *key*.

*Supports value equality.*

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 100, bar: 200]
map.update("foo", 0, &.succ) # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 101, "bar" => 200}
map.update("baz", 0, &.succ) # => Pf::Map{"foo" => 100, "bar" => 200, "baz" => 0}
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns an updated copy of self.

def.name: update
def.body:
cloak = @node.find?(key)
cloak ? assoc(key, yield cloak.unwrap) : assoc(key, default)

instance_methods.name: values
instance_methods.doc:
Returns an array with all values from this map. There is no
guaranteed order of values.

```
map = Pf::Map[foo: 10, bar: 20]
map.values # => [10, 20]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns an array with all values from this map.

def.name: values
def.body:
values = Array(V).new(size)
each_value do |key|
  values << key
end
values

types.name: Set
types.doc:
A thread-safe, persistent, unordered set.

See also: `Map`.

class_methods.doc:
Returns a new set with the given *elements*.

The type of the returned set is the union of the types of *elements*.

```
set = Pf::Set[1, "Hello", 3, true]
set # => Pf::Set[1, "Hello", 3, true]

typeof(set) # => Pf::Set(String | Int32 | Bool)
```
class_methods.summary: Returns a new set with the given elements.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Returns a new set with the elements from *enumerable*.

```
set = Pf::Set.new([1, 2, 3])
set # => Pf::Set[1, 2, 3]
```
constructors.summary: Returns a new set with the elements from enumerable.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc:
Returns a new, empty set.

```
set = Pf::Set(Int32).new
set.empty? => true
```

instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new set containing elements common to this and *other* sets.

```
a = Pf::Set[1, 2, 3]
b = Pf::Set[4, 5, 1, 6, 2]
a & b # => Pf::Set[1, 2]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new set containing elements common to this and other sets.

def.body:
smallest, largest = size < other.size ? {self, other} : {other, self}
smallest.select do |element|
  element.in?(largest)
end

instance_methods.doc: Shorthand for `concat`.
instance_methods.summary: Shorthand for #concat.

instance_methods.doc: Returns `true` if two sets are equal.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if two sets are equal.

def.body:
if @map == (other.@map)
else
  return false
end
true

instance_methods.doc:
Same as `Set#===`.

```
reds = Pf::Set["red", "pink", "violet"]
blues = Pf::Set["blue", "azure", "violet"]

both = red = blue = false

case "violet"
when reds & blues
  both = true
when reds
  red = true
when blues
  blue = true
end

both # => true
red  # => false
blue # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Same as Set#===.

instance_methods.name: add
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of this set that includes *element*.

*Supports value equality*.

```
set = Pf::Set[100, 200]
set.add(300) # => Pf::Set[100, 200, 300]
set.add(400) # => Pf::Set[100, 200, 400]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of this set that includes element.

instance_methods.name: concat
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of this set that also includes elements from
*other* enumerable.

*Supports value equality*.

```
a = Pf::Set[1, 2, 3]
a.concat([4, 5, 1, 2]) # => Pf::Set[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of this set that also includes elements from other enumerable.

instance_methods.name: delete
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a copy of this set that is guaranteed not to include
*element*.

```
set = Pf::Set[100, 200, 300]
set.delete(100) # => Pf::Set[200, 300]
set.delete(200) # => Pf::Set[100, 300]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a copy of this set that is guaranteed not to include element.

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.doc: Yields each element from this set.
instance_methods.summary: Yields each element from this set.

instance_methods.name: empty?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if this set is empty.

```
set = Pf::Set(Int32).new
set.empty? # => true

newset = set.add(100)
newset.empty? # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this set is empty.

instance_methods.name: fmap
instance_methods.doc:
Yields each element from this set to the block and constructs
a new set from block return results.

Supports value equality if `T == U`.

```
set = Pf::Set[1, 2, 3]
set.fmap(&.succ.to_s) # => Pf::Set["2", "3", "4"]
```
instance_methods.summary: Yields each element from this set to the block and constructs a new set from block return results.

instance_methods.name: hash
instance_methods.doc: See `Object#hash(hasher)`.
instance_methods.summary: See Object#hash(hasher).

def.name: hash
def.body:
result = hasher.result
copy = hasher
copy = self.class.hash(copy)
result = result &+ copy.result
copy = hasher
copy = @map.hash(copy)
result = result &+ copy.result
result.hash(hasher)

instance_methods.name: includes?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if *element* is present in this set.

```
set = Pf::Set[1, 2, 3]

1.in?(set)        # => true
2.in?(set)        # => true
3.in?(set)        # => true
100.in?(set)      # => false
"foobar".in?(set) # => false
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if element is present in this set.

instance_methods.name: inspect
instance_methods.doc: Alias of `#to_s`.
instance_methods.summary: Alias of #to_s.

instance_methods.name: reject
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new set that includes only elements for which the
block is *falsey*.

*Supports value equality*.

```
set = (0...10).to_pf_set
set.reject(&.even?) # => Pf::Set[1, 3, 5, 7, 9]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new set that includes only elements for which the block is falsey.

instance_methods.name: same?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns `true` if `self` and *other* refer to the same set in memory.

Due to the way `Set` is implemented, this method can be used as
a cheap way to detect changes.

```
set1 = Pf::Set[1, 2, 3]
set2 = set1.add(1).add(2).add(3)
set1.same?(set2) # => true
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if self and other refer to the same set in memory.

instance_methods.name: select
instance_methods.doc:
Returns a new set that includes only elements for which the
block is *truthy*.

*Supports value equality*.

```
set = (0...10).to_pf_set
set.select(&.even?) # => Pf::Set[0, 2, 4, 6, 8]
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns a new set that includes only elements for which the block is truthy.

instance_methods.name: size
instance_methods.doc:
Returns the number of elements in this set.

```
set = Pf::Set[1, 5]
set.size # => 2
```
instance_methods.summary: Returns the number of elements in this set.
